projects.title: Rent scraper
projects.description:
February 5, 2026

We're looking for larger place to live but there aren't many larger houses for rent.
It's getting quite tiring to check 10+ real estate pages from time to time, so would be great if I could make a scraper that pulls in new houses for rent that match my requirements.

projects.title: Liquor rater
projects.description:
February 3, 2026

There's Vivino for wines and Untappd for beers but what about liquors?
Don't judge me.
I received a set of about 20 whisky and rhum samples. And I also got 12 last year. They're only 2cl each but I want a place to track and rate them.

Claude Code very quickly created an HMTL file that basically does everything. It seemed functional, but no separate style sheet and no separate database sound wrong to me.

Claude split it up into a js server, json files for data and css style sheet. Still looks the same. Impressive. 

Currently no public repo, might push it later if it looks better.

Separating tabs for collection and adding a new entry really made it look better.

---

February 4, 2026

Tried to implement voice transcription as well last night, but that didn't seem to work because it needs internet access and this is a local app (for now).
So I'm going to include OCR instead to speed up text input. That seems to work better.
I'm also making some changes to the layout and card field: adding years of aging and putting it in two columns so it stays in one screen.

projects.title: Vibing tracker
projects.description:
January 29, 2026

Tried to deploy the Vibe coding Activity Tracker online by setting up GitHub Pages with automatic deployment and configured local SiteGround deployment via SFTP.                              

Unfortunately, Siteground wasn't really working along as the files could not be pushed.

At some point I managed to show my page successfully on vibing.kjellv.com but without actually showing my activity.

Almost there but not quite yet.

---

January 30, 2026

I gave up trying to push the files directly to Siteground. 
With a CNAME record, however, my github page now gets shown on vibing.kjellv.com
This requires a workflow in github that Claude wrote.

Additionally, i added a cron job to parse my Obsidian files daily and push the changes to github so that my activity tracker gets updated daily (when I'm online)

Finally, I added a button in the header to go back to kjellv.com. Believe it or not, I coded this manually with some HTML and CSS. At least I have the feeling that I contributed a bit now.

---

February 4, 2026

Made some small changes to how projects and days are being parsed.
One project per note file: Each Obsidian note is now treated as a single project, regardless of how many date sections (H2 headers) it contains. 
Chronological ordering: Date sections within a note are now sorted chronologically (oldest to newest) before being processed and aggregated.
Aggregated content: All work sessions from different dates are combined into a single project entry with:
• The earliest date as the main project date
• All content from all sessions aggregated
• All learnings combined
• Maximum intensity across all sessions
• A new workDates array that tracks all the dates you worked on that project
Clean titles: Project titles no longer have "(Day 1)", "(Day 2)" labels.

---

February 5, 2026

The changes from yesterday didn't really work out the way I wanted.
I trusted Claude to just change everything at once but it didn't work.
I then tried again, giving more and clearer instructions but it almost reversed the changes instead.
Today, I tried implementing the small changes one by one, instead.

projects.title: Sally, customer success oracle
projects.description:
January 28, 2026

Just made a Slack bot that everyone in the team can talk to to ask questions about our successful customers. 

But it can also answer other questions like: 
• Which customers are in IT? 
• Which customers have an office manager? 
• Who had the most impressions last year? 

How does it work? 

Two simple n8n workflows. 
Every time a new success story gets added (or updated) to Webflow, it gets synced to a database 
Slack messages get passed on to an AI Agent who only takes the database as a single source of truth. The reply gets sent back to the same slack channel.

---

January 29, 2026

Sally lives on ww.willow.co/success-stories too now.
Been wanting to implement this for months but never felt confident about how to do it.
Since I got more experience with webhooks now, I gave it another shot and it was easier than expected.
Starting with a script for Webflow written by ChatGPT, it was easy enough to connect it to n8n and send back replies to the web page. 
Styling it was something I could easily do manually as well.
Pretty happy with the result.

projects.title: Newsletter automater
projects.description:
January 26, 2026

Added a timestamp to yaml so I kind of have a feeling which emails I should read first.
Also updated the script so it only processes unread emails instead of all emails.
Then I ran the script again and I deleted everything from the gmail folders.
Hope I didn't miss anything :)

Definitely already noticed that I'm much more likely to open the emails from Obsidian than from my email app when I'm looking for something to do while waiting.

projects.title: Wardrobe
projects.description:
January 16, 2026

First time working with Claude Code. Developed fully locally.
Learning here is that the main file is definitely too large. 
Wondering why CSS isn't separated for example.
Also the stack was too light to make it work visually, but again maybe it's related to the CSS too.
Good but expensive learning experience (around 28$)

---

January 27, 2026
Converted desktop app to web app - Transformed the CustomTkinter desktop wardrobe manager into a Flask-based web application
Unified database - Merged separate wardrobe.db and wardrobe_fer.db into single database with `wardrobe` field to distinguish owners
Added search & filter - Implemented debounced search (300ms), type filtering, and sorting by rating/brand/date
Built REST API - Created 10+ Flask endpoints for CRUD operations, search, filter, sort, and undo functionality
Vanilla JS frontend - Developed SPA with state management, API client, and modular components (ItemCard, ItemModal, SearchFilter)
CSS theme system - Implemented CSS variables for instant theme switching between Kjell's earthy and Fer's pink color schemes
Preserved features - Maintained all original functionality: color-coded cards, 10-star ratings, color picker, edit/delete with undo
Migrated 72 items - Successfully transferred all items from Kjell's wardrobe with full data integrity and backups
Responsive design - Built mobile-friendly grid layout with auto-fill columns and media queries for various screen sizes
Complete documentation - Created README, INSTALL, QUICKSTART guides plus verification scripts for easy setup and troubleshooting

Key Features
• View items organized by clothing type
• Add/edit/delete items with confirmation
• Color-coded item cards with contrast text
• 10-star rating system
• Color picker for custom colors
• Switch between Kjell's and Fer's wardrobes
• Undo delete (10-second window)
• Automatic data persistence
• Search - Full-text search across brand, model, materials with debouncing
• Filter - Dropdown to filter by specific clothing type
• Sort - Multiple sort options (rating desc, brand asc, date desc)
• Responsive - Mobile-friendly grid layout
• Keyboard shortcuts - ESC to close modals
• Real-time updates - Observer pattern for reactive UI
• API access - RESTful endpoints for external integration

Access at: http://localhost:5001 (changed from 5000 to avoid macOS AirPlay conflict)
